Technical Assistance Report
 
Project Number: 44103-1 
Research and Development Technical Assistance (RDTA) 
November 2010 
 
 
 
Sovereign Debt Sustainability in Asia and the Pacific
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS

  ADO  –  Asian Development Outlook

(ERD)

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

1 
I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Fiscal  sustainability  has  not  traditionally  been  a  major  policy  concern  in  most  of 
developing Asia. Because of conservative policies and speedy responses to fiscal slippages, 
budget deficits in the Asia and Pacific have generally been small, and public debt (in relation to 
gross domestic product [GDP]) has not reached the high levels seen in other parts of the world. 
This is not to say that developing Asia has been immune from sovereign debt crises, particularly 
involving external foreign-currency-denominated debt. Many Asian countries have experienced 
crises either individually (for example, Indonesia in the 1960s, India in the 1970s, and the 
Philippines in the 1980s) or as part of a wider regional trend such as the 1997–1998 Asian 
financial crisis. After the Asian financial crisis, fiscal positions improved across developing Asia, 
substantially lowering public debt ratios. Some countries endorsed rules for fiscal discipline and 
in pursuit of debt targets. In the meantime, countries with persistent current account surpluses 
were piling up foreign exchange reserves to protect against speculative attacks, external shocks, 
or sudden capital reversals.  
 
2.  The 2008–2009 global financial crisis spurned massive government stimulus programs 
worldwide in an effort to keep economies afloat. Before the crisis, countries in developing Asia 
benefited from fiscal positions that provided plenty of space for fiscal intervention, which they 
used extensively to support their economies. The crisis inevitably caused fiscal positions to 
deteriorate across Asian Development Bank (ADB) developing member countries (DMCs). Debt 
ratios spiked and debt sustainability was affected, but to varying degrees among DMCs. The 
research and development technical assistance (TA) for Sovereign Debt Sustainability in Asia 
and the Pacific will assess the sustainability of sovereign debt in developing Asia.1 The design 
and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Sovereign  debt  sustainability  refers  to  a  country's  ability  to  continue  servicing  its 
domestic or external public debt without an unrealistically large future correction to the budget or 
the balance of payments. Fiscal sustainability refers to a country's ability to smoothly finance the 
budget without generating explosive increases in public debt. External debt sustainability refers 
to  a  country's  ability  to  meet  current  and  future  external  obligations  without  arrears,  debt 
rescheduling, and/or an eventual drastic adjustment of the balance of payments. 
 
4.  The Asian Development Outlook 20102 report (ADO 2010) and ADB Economics Working 
Paper Series No. 2053 analyzed the implications of the global economic downturn on fiscal 
health in developing Asia. The main finding was that a history of fiscal rectitude provided Asian 
countries with the policy space and fiscal muscle to intervene vigorously when the global crisis 
hit and demand for Asian exports stalled. However, the ADO 2010 also noted that it is risky to 
keep fiscal spending at crisis levels for too long, as it may cause debt ratios to balloon. By 
contrast,  a  gradual  return  to  pre-crisis  fiscal  rectitude,  combined  with  strong  economic 
expansion and a moderate increase in interest rates over time, was shown to project into debt 
ratios that did not raise concerns about sovereign debt sustainability. 
 
                                                 
1  The TA concept paper was cleared on 22 July 2010. The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of 
ADB’s website on 8 October 2010. 
2  ADB. 2010. Asian Development Outlook 2010. Manila. 
3  C. Adams, B. Ferrarini, and D. Park. 2010. Fiscal Sustainability in Developing Asia. ADB Economics Working 
Paper Series No. 205. Manila: Asian Development Bank.

2         
5.  Although ADO 2010 found Asia and the Pacific as a whole to be on a sound fiscal 
footing, the picture gets more nuanced for individual DMCs. Some countries' debt ratios are 
beyond comfort levels or may become unsustainable if assumptions about future growth and 
interest rates prove overly optimistic. Moreover, sustainability concerns are likely to increase if 
forecasting scenarios envisaged a broader range of shocks economies may be subjected to in 
the future, such as a sharp rise in interest rates or a marked slowdown of economic growth.  
 
6.  Assessing sovereign debt sustainability in developing Asia more thoroughly will require a 
broader range of analytical methods, including stochastic simulation.4 Compared with the simple 
deterministic  projections  underlying  standard  methods  of  assessing  debt  sustainability, 
stochastic simulation more effectively accounts for historical patterns of relationships among the 
determinants of debt ratios (e.g., GDP growth, interest rates, exchange rates, primary deficits), 
and  accounts  for  a  broader  range  of  shocks  and  combinations  that  might  affect  debt 
sustainability. On the downside, stochastic analysis is more data-intensive and less transparent 
than simple debt projections.  
 
7.  Analyses of debt sustainability should reflect the structure and composition of public debt, 
as well as institutional characteristics that may complicate a country’s debt dynamics. For 
example, countries facing highly decentralized sovereign debt usually find it more difficult to rein 
in local government debt and profligacy compared with countries that merely manage central 
debt accounts. Because of scarce data, such issues are often disregarded by standard debt 
sustainability analysis, and require instead in-depth country knowledge and the use of ad hoc 
assessment methods.  
 
8.  Finally, in some countries sustainability problems may arise because of large contingent 
liabilities and publicly guaranteed debt, whether in connection with state-owned enterprises, 
quasi-public entities, or implicit guarantees extended to private sector debt. Other countries face 
debt sustainability concerns not so much because of past borrowing but as a reflection of future 
fiscal  gaps  resulting  from  demographic  pressures  from,  for  instance,  aging  populations  or 
growing dependency ratios. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
9.  This TA will assess sovereign debt sustainability in the Asia and Pacific region. The first 
component of this project will consist of a conceptual study reviewing alternative approaches to 
debt sustainability assessment, including stochastic analysis to account for contingent liabilities.  
 
10.  The second component will build on the empirical analysis of the ADO 2010, which 
focused mainly on regions, updating the analysis with the most recent post-crisis debt and 
macroeconomic data and upgrading the assessment methodology for all DMCs where sufficient 
data is available. The sustainability assessment will also factor in contingent liabilities and 
implicit  government  guarantees  to  reflect  transfer  risks  from  semi-public  entities  and  the 
commercial finance sector. A by-product of this analysis will be the collection of detailed public 
debt and fiscal data for DMCs to update and expand the database that was originally compiled 
for the background work on the ADO 2010. 
 
                                                 
4  Stochastic simulation refers to the probabilistic approach to debt sustainability analysis. Simply put, it consists of 
repeated simulations of random shocks, from which large samples of sovereign debt projections are constructed 
over the simulation horizon. The corresponding frequency distributions yield a probabilistic assessment of debt 
dynamics.

3 
11.  The third and most central component of this TA will consist of four country studies. 
Drawing on consultants’ specific country knowledge and expertise and a deeper pool of data 
and information sources, these analyses will assess debt sustainability in depth in the four 
selected countries and lay out the policy implications. The lessons from country experiences will 
be summarized to serve the broader discussion of debt sustainability in Asia and the Pacific. An 
inception workshop and insights from past research will help pinpoint which countries out of 
those  facing  sovereign  debt  issues  are  most  suitable  for  the  case  studies.  The  selected 
countries should be from different regions of developing Asia and should be at different levels of 
economic development. Other factors influencing country selection include data constraints and 
the availability of consultants with sufficient country expertise. 
 
12.  The findings of this TA will be published as an edited research volume (book) of thematic, 
empirical, and country studies. Research methods and outputs will be discussed at country 
workshops that will bring together ADB staff, international consultants, and other stakeholders. 
Selected  studies  will  also  be  presented  at  international  conferences  and  submitted  for 
publication in scholarly journals. Policy notes will be disseminated to the general public through 
the media.  
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
13.  The impact of this TA will be to contribute to the implementation and interpretation of 
sovereign debt sustainability assessments in Asia and the Pacific. An additional impact of this 
TA  will  be  an  increased  perception  of  ADB  as  a  knowledge  creator  in  the  field  of  debt 
sustainability assessment, through TA workshops, publications, and the dissemination of policy 
notes. 
 
14.  The outcome of this TA will be a more thorough understanding of the determinants and 
risks underlying sovereign debt sustainability in Asia and the Pacific. 
 
15.  The output of this TA will be an edited book comprising the conceptual study, the 
empirical study, and the country studies. The planned table of contents of the book is included 
in Appendix 4. An additional output of this TA will be an up-to-date database of public debt and 
fiscal data across DMCs.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
16.  The TA will hire a lead consultant to provide the conceptual study and to assist with the 
coordination of the project jointly with the ADB team. Four additional consultants with in-depth 
country knowledge and experience will be hired for the country studies. These experts will 
identify the methods most suitable for assessing debt sustainability in the countries selected for 
country studies. The focus and methods of the country studies are likely to differ substantially 
from country to country. Additional resource persons will be hired as needed to provide, for 
example, technical support for the empirical study of debt, including stochastic simulations, in 
collaboration with ADB team members. A national consultant will be hired to assist with logistics 
and administrative matters and provide data support and research assistance. 
 
17.  The analytical framework adopted for the conceptual and empirical studies will build on 
the  analysis  in  ADO  2010  and  the  ADB  Economics  Working  Paper  Series  No.  205.  The 
conceptual  study  will  provide  a  review  of  sovereign  debt  sustainability  and  the  various 
assessment methodologies. The approach will be to combine a rigorous analytical review with 
practical considerations of assessment methods at the country level, to provide a useful, hands-

4         
on discussion for policy makers in developing Asia. The empirical study will implement a range 
of debt accounting and simulation methodologies, both deterministic and probabilistic. This will 
entail computing fiscal sustainability indicators, estimating policy reaction functions (i.e., the 
extent  to  which  DMC  governments  adjust  primary  deficits  to  changes  in  debt  ratios),  and 
implementing stochastic assessment methods for countries where sufficient data is available.  
 
18.  ADB team members, project consultants, and resource persons will finalize the research 
plan and select the countries for case studies at an inception workshop at ADB headquarters. 
Subsequently, a workshop will be held in each of the selected countries, bringing together 
country authorities and local stakeholders with the ADB team members and the international 
consultant performing the country analysis. Upon the draft country studies being completed, 
country authorities and/or local experts and scholars will be invited to contribute commentary on 
each study for inclusion in the book.  
 
19.  The research will be disseminated by presenting the research studies at international 
conferences and disseminating policy notes to the media. The main research outputs will be 
presented and discussed at a conference at ADB headquarters, and will be edited for book 
publication. A book launch and media event will conclude the TA.   
 
20.  The  major  assumptions  and  risks  of  the  TA  concern  the  availability  of  qualified 
consultants,  as  sovereign  debt  issues  and  debt  sustainability  analysis  is  a  narrow  and 
specialized field. It may prove difficult to find consultants that have both the technical expertise 
and  the  country  knowledge  to  produce  debt  sustainability  assessments  and  policy 
recommendations that add substantial value to other organizations’ extensive work in the field—
most notably the International Monetary Fund (IMF). 
 
21.  Another area of difficulty concerns the scarcity of data. For many developing countries—
particularly the low income countries—fiscal records and debt data are notoriously incomplete 
and of low quality. Data issues at the country level may undermine the scope and range of 
empirical analysis, and computational differences may render the data largely incomparable 
across countries. Moreover, country authorities tend to be sensitive about the release of fiscal 
data, and IMF datasets are usually not in the public domain. Obtaining data on DMCs for the 
ADO 2010 involved a painstaking process of extracting data from a large amount of IMF and 
other official country documents and reports.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
22.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $455,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on 
a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The financing will cover 
the remuneration, per diem, and travel expenses of international consultants as well as the 
travel expenses of ADB team members, travel expenses of conference and workshop resource 
persons, report production, equipment, and other miscellaneous expenses. The cost estimates 
and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
23.  ADB will be the executing agency. The TA will build on the inputs of consultants hired for 
this project, as well as on the inputs of ADB team members working in collaboration with the 
lead consultant on the empirical study, project supervision, and final editing of the book chapters. 
Counterpart institutions will not play a substantive role. However, sporadic collaboration with

5 
DMC governments5 and other stakeholders, including the IMF and the World Bank, will be 
sought,  mainly  in  the  form  of  data  input  or  participation  in  workshops.  The  TA  will  be 
implemented over 20 months (December 2010–July 2012). 
 
24.  The TA will require 6 months of international consulting. One lead consultant (economist) 
will be hired for 2 person-months to coordinate the technical aspects throughout the course of 
the project and to edit the final research outputs jointly with the ADB team members. The lead 
consultant will also contribute to the conceptual study. Four consultants will be hired for 1 
person-month each to conduct the country studies. A national consultant will be hired for 8 
person-months to help with the logistics and organizational matters, and to provide research 
assistance. Resource persons will be invited to provide specific inputs, such as technical advice 
on a particular simulation technique, or to comment on draft studies.  
 
25.  The consultants will be selected and hired individually by ADB in accordance with its 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The outline terms 
of reference for consultants is in Appendix 3. Disbursements under the project will follow ADB’s 
Technical  Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  To 
support the database compilation and simulations, software (e.g., Stata 64-bit, MatLab) and 
computer  equipment  will  be  purchased  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines 
(2010, as amended from time to time) and in coordination with ADB’s Office of Information 
Systems  and  Technology  and  Office  of  Administrative  Services,  where  applicable.  The 
equipment purchased under the TA will be turned over to ADB upon completion of the TA. 
 
26.  Disseminating the outputs and outcome evaluation will involve one workshop in each of 
the countries selected for the case studies. These events and related follow-up discussions will 
provide ample opportunities for exchanges between TA research staff, consultants, and local 
stakeholders. Outcome evaluation will be gathered also by soliciting commentary on country 
studies from local experts, such as finance ministers, to be incorporated into the final report. A 
concluding TA conference on debt sustainability in Asia and the Pacific will serve as a broader 
platform of dialogue and evaluation of this project, involving representatives from government 
and partner institutions. Peer review of conceptual, empirical and country studies will assess the 
quality of the book. Research findings and policy notes will be disseminated through workshops 
and conferences, publication of the edited book, and media exposure.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
27.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $455,000 on a grant basis for 
Sovereign Debt Sustainability in Asia and the Pacific, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.  
 
                                                 
5 A no-objection letter from the chosen DMC will be sought before the TA is implemented in any particular country.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Consultants will be engaged on an individual basis to provide technical services under 
the research and development technical assistance (TA) for Sovereign Debt Sustainability in 
Asia and the Pacific. Consultant inputs will total 14 person-months, including 6 person-months 
of international and 8 person-months of national consultant inputs. The indicative time allocation 
and outline terms of reference follow. 
 
A.  International Consultants 
1.  Lead Consultant (1 consultant, 2 person-months) 
2.  The lead consultant should have a proven track record as a project advisor or team 
leader  in  similar  assignments,  and  should  have  expertise  in  sovereign  debt  and  debt 
sustainability analysis. Under the supervision of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) team 
leader, the international expert will: 
(i)  coordinate the work and outputs of other international consultants, jointly with the 
ADB team,  
(ii)  provide the conceptual study on debt sustainability analysis, 
(iii)  contribute to drafting the introduction and concluding chapters of the book, jointly 
with the ADB team, 
(iv)  review and edit the final project report, for book publication, jointly with the ADB 
team,  
(v)  participate in TA-related conferences and workshops, and 
(vi)  provide other research and project-related inputs as required. 
 
3.  The lead consultant should have (i) a doctorate degree in economics or equivalent 
qualification; (ii) expert knowledge of development issues in developing Asia, as demonstrated 
by a relevant publication record; (iii) proven capacity to conduct both analytical and empirical 
work of highest quality in the field of sovereign debt; and (iv) proven capacity to synthesize 
complex  issues  and  identify  key  policy  messages  for  policy  makers,  donors,  and  other 
stakeholders. 
 
2.  Consultants (4 consultants, 4 person-months total) 
 
4.  Under  the  supervision  of  the  lead  consultant  and  the  ADB  team  leader,  the  four 
international experts will:  
 
(i)  conceptualize and undertake debt sustainability analyses for the four countries 
selected for case studies, 
(ii)  provide country studies for inclusion in the book, 
(iii)  present their findings in the form of ADB working papers and/or journal articles, 
(iv)  participate in TA-related conferences and workshops, and 
(v)  provide other research and project-related inputs as required. 
 
5.  Each international expert should have (i) a doctorate degree in economics or equivalent 
qualification; (ii) expert knowledge of development issues in the country to which they are 
assigned, as demonstrated by a relevant publication record; (iii) proven capacity to conduct both 
analytical and empirical work of highest quality in the field of sovereign debt; and (iv) proven

capacity to synthesize complex issues and identify key policy messages for policymakers, 
donors, and other stakeholders. 
 
B.  National Consultant 
 
1.  Project Coordinator (1 consultant, 8 person-months) 
 
6.  The  project  coordinator  should  have  a  relevant  master’s  degree  and  substantial 
experience  in  project  management  and  basic  research  assistance.  In  collaboration  with  a 
designated ADB national officer, the consultant will handle the logistics and communications for 
the TA. The consultant will be engaged on a part-time basis at ADB headquarters. Under the 
supervision of the ADB research team, the  project coordinator will: 
 
(i)  provide  overall  coordination,  communications,  and  logistical  support  for  the 
project;  
(ii)  help organize the TA workshops and conferences; 
(iii)  help collect data and other key information from various multilateral, bilateral, and 
national agencies for use in the project; and 
(iv)  assist  with  the  overall  management  of  the  project  and  provide  research 
assistance as required.
